locality: Monte Azul, Serra de Montevidéu, Morro das Marombas, 1150 m
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364423X16758873924090 Etymology: 'The specific epithet congestifolium (from Latin congestus = gathered, densely agglomerated + folium = leaf) refers to the leaves crowded at the apex of the branches'.

name: Pleroma curucutuense
collectorTeam: F.S. Meyer, M. Reginato, R. Goldenberg & R.J.F. Garcia
distribution: São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Municipality of São Paulo, Parque Estadual da Serra do Mar-Núcleo Curucutu
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.616.1.7 Etymology: refers to the Núcleo Curucutu, a subunit of the Parque Estadual da Serra do Mar and the only place of occurrence for the species until now; the toponym 'Curucutu' is of onomatopoeia origin, in reference to the hoot of an owl.

name: Pleroma eglanduliferum
collectorTeam: L.L. Justino, J.H.C Ribeiro,  M.C.A Mota, J.F.B Pastore
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Rio Preto. Serra Negra,  trail for the Burro de Ouro, 1400 m
remarks: doi:10.1590/2236-8906-76/2020 Etymology: name refers to the absence of glands over the stamen connective, including appendices of both whorles.

name: Pleroma ferricola
typeLocations: holotype BHCB;isotype HUFU;isotype MO;isotype RB;isotype US
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Pleroma goyazense
locality: Mossâmedes, Parque Estadual da Serra Dourada, próximo ao Mirante, 975 m
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.622.3.4 Etymology: name refers to the restricted occurrence of the new species in the state of Goiás, Brazil, using the original spelling 'Goyaz', which was replaced by Goiás in 1943.

name: Pleroma guartelaensis
locality: Município de Tibagi, Parque Estadual do Guartelá

name: Pleroma joelsilvae
typeLocations: holotype UPCB;isotype FUEL;isotype HCF;isotype MBM;isotype RB
locality: Castro, PCH Rio Iapó – Fazenda Marumbi, 980 m
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.554.3.4 Etymology: 'The epithet “joelsilvae” is a tribute to Joel Morais da Silva, for his extensive work as a plant collector and as part of the staff of the “Museu Botânico Municipal de Curitiba”.'

name: Pleroma kollmanniana
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Santa Teresa, “Pedra da Onça” (cultivated at Santa Teresa, in the “Museu de Biologia Mello Leitão”)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.282.3.3 the epithet honors Ludovic Jean Charles Kollmann, botanist and important plant collector in Espírito Santo, including several new species of Pleroma

name: Pleroma leopoldinensis
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Santa Leopoldina, estrada para o Rio das Farinhas

name: Pleroma littorale
distribution: Paraná (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America);Santa Catarina (Brazil South, Brazil, Southern America);São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.638.3.1 Etymology: name refers to its occurrence in coastal areas.

name: Pleroma martinellii
typeLocations: holotype RB;isotype BHCB;isotype HUFU;isotype NY;isotype UPCB
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Monte Azul, Serra de Montevidéu, Morro das Marombas, 1180 m
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364423X16758873924090 Etymology: In honour of Brazilian botanist Professor Dr Gustavo Martinelli (1953–).

name: Pleroma miconiifolium
collectorTeam: P.M.Gonella, D.P.Cordeiro, G.A.da Silva, P.R.Bartholomay & L.Medeiros
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Santa Rita do Itueto, A.P.A. Municipal Pedra do Paredão, Pedra de Santa Rita, na encosta do topo da pedra, 1060 m
remarks: doi:10.24823/EJB.2022.624 Etymology: the specific epithet refers to the similarity of the leaves of this species to those of the genus Miconia Ruiz & Pav. (Melastomataceae), which often have pocket domatia on their abaxial surface.

name: Pleroma penduliflora
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Mun. Pancas, Serra do Mutum Preto, 750 m

name: Pleroma petrophylax
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Conselheiro Pena, afloramento quartzítico próximo a Vista Alegre (distrito de Alvarenga), 980 m
remarks: doi:10.24823/EJB.2022.624 Etymology: the specific epithet derives from the Greek pétra for 'rock', and phylax, phylakos for 'guardian', 'protector'. It refers to the singular habitat of this new species, the rocky outcrops of the Atlantic Rain Forest, where it remained even after the intense destruction of the vegetation at this biodiversity hotspot.

name: Pleroma piranii
collectorTeam: F. Almeda, R. Romero, O. Robinson & D. Robinson
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Santana do Riacho ['Jaboticatubas'], Serra do Cipó, entre Km 112 e 113 na estrada para Conceição do Mato Dentro, 1280 m
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.560.1.2 Etymology: honours Dr. José Rubens Pirani (1953–), Professor of Botany at the University of São Paulo and Curator of the SPF herbarium.

name: Pleroma semisterile
typeLocations: holotype RB;isotype BHCB;isotype HUEFS;isotype MBM;isotype MBML;isotype SPF;isotype UPCB;isotype VIES
collectorTeam: F.M. Arantes, L.F.A. de Paula & R. Carvalho
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Pancas, Monumento Natural dos Pontões Capixabas, Pedra da Mula
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.638.3.1 Etymology: name refers to the pollen-empty anthers in the antesepalous stamen whorl, contrasting with the fully fertile, pollen-filled anthers in the antepetalous whorl; these five sterile plus five fertile anthers make the androecium half-sterile.

name: Pleroma subsessilis
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Afonso Cláudio, Alto Três Pontões (Pico da Antena de Rádio Amador)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.282.3.3 the epithet subsessilis is related to the leaves with very short petioles
